#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|

#Text=Low retention of restocked laboratory_reared long_spined sea urchins�Diadema antillarum�due to Spanish hogfish�Bodianus rufus�predation.

#Text=Tom Wijers,�Oliver Klokman,�Albertinka J Murk,�Jilles Sijbrandij,�Alwin Hylkema\rFirst published: 12 September 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14264\rAuthor contributions: OK, JS, AH conceived and designed the research; OK, JS, AH performed the experiments; TW, OK, JS, AH analyzed the data; TW, OK, AJM, JS, AH wrote and edited the manuscript; OK, TW contributed equally to this study.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Joanne Preston\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.
#Text=The die_off of the long_spined sea urchin Diadema antillarum�in the 1980s highlighted its crucial role as a primary grazer in tropical western Atlantic coral reefs.
#Text=However, natural recovery has been slow, exacerbated by a new die_off in 2022.
#Text=Interest in actively restoring�D. antillarum�populations has grown with the emergence of culture and rearing techniques.
#Text=Restocking reefs with laboratory_reared urchins shows potential for enhancing coral reef resilience by reducing algal cover and promoting coral settlement, but success rates vary.
#Text=Predation and migration contribute to low retention rates, with distinguishing between them is challenging.

#Text=In this study near Saba, Caribbean Netherlands, we released 200 laboratory_reared�D. antillarum�on a reef and monitored for�D. antillarum�retention and potential�D. antillarum�predator presence and interaction for 35 days.
#Text=Only 40% of the urchins were still present on the reef after day one.
#Text=The Spanish hogfish�Bodianus rufus�was identified as the primary daytime predator, responsible for nine direct predation events.
#Text=No nighttime predation was observed, but interaction with a batwing coral crab�Carpilius corallinus�was noted.
#Text=These insights can help optimize future restocking attempts and emphasize� the importance of assessing predator presence beforehand.
#Text=Reefs with high abundances of predators such as Spanish hogfish should be avoided for�D antillarum�restocking.
#Text=In addition, before being released, lab_reared animals should be given time to acclimate to conditions in the wild by being placed in protected in situ cages.
#Text=Here, they could also grow to larger sizes that are less vulnerable to predation.
#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Site selection based on predation pressure and shelter availability could increase retention of restocked�Diadema antillarum.

#Text=Sites with high Spanish hogfish or queen triggerfish abundances should be avoided unless temporal predator control is possible.\r* Scaling up larval culture techniques and juvenile rearing methods are necessary to effectively restore�D. antillarum�populations with a significant impact on a local and regional scale.\r* Laboratory_reared sea urchins should be acclimated in a protected semi_natural environment before restocking to increase survival.\r* Further studies are needed to determine the optimal�D. antillarum�size for restocking to maximize survival and minimize resource use.
#Text=Introduction.

#Text=Human activities have clearly influenced coral reef ecosystems for centuries, primarily through overfishing, destructive fishing methods, direct reef damage, and the introduction of pollutants (Pandolfi et al�2003).

#Text=These anthropogenic factors have led to a pronounced reduction in coral cover, diminished biodiversity, and the deterioration of the essential structural characteristics provided by coral reefs (Eddy et al�2021).

#Text=Particularly, tropical western Atlantic coral reefs have experienced substantial and enduring degradation (Mumby et al�2007), with a marked decrease in coral cover in recent decades (Jackson et al�2014).

#Text=This decline has been further exacerbated by additional stressors, including the impacts of hurricanes, the proliferation of coral diseases (Aronson & Precht�2001; Precht et al�2016), climate change induced coral bleaching events (Sully et al�2019), and the extensive mortality of a keystone herbivore species, the long_spined sea urchin�Diadema antillarum�in the 1980s (Lessios et al�1984).

#Text=In the absence of grazing by�D. antillarum, turf algae, and macroalgae cover increased on the majority of coral reefs (Carpenter�1986; Hughes et al�1987; Lessios�1988), inhibiting recruitment and leaving the reefs in a coral degraded state (Mumby�2009).
#Text=Since the mass mortality in the 1980s, the recovery of�D. antillarum�has been slow, with an average of 12% over a span of 30 years (Lessios�2016).

#Text=On reefs where�D. antillarum�populations have recovered, algae cover was reduced, and coral recruitment increased (Aronson & Precht�2000; Idjadi et al�2010), underscoring the critical significance of�D. antillarum�in the recovery of Caribbean reefs.

#Text=Several restoration methods, such as restocking (Chiappone et al�2003; Macia et al�2007; Williams�2022) and assisted natural recovery (Hylkema et al�2022), have the potential to accelerate the pace of�D. antillarum�recovery.

#Text=Restocking can be done with cultured�D. antillarum�(Pilnick et al�2022; Wijers et al�2023) or collected settlers reared in tanks (Williams�2018,�2022; de Breuyn et al�2023), but has mostly been done by translocating individuals from recovered populations to experimental plots (Nedimyer & Moe�2006; de Breuyn et al�2023; Pilnick et al�2023).
#Text=Some studies show encouraging results, with positive effects on the reefs after restocking with�D. antillarum.
#Text=Chiappone et al (2003) translocated a total of 693 juvenile�D. antillarum�with 30% retention after 1 year.
#Text=This resulted in a reduced cover of brown foliose algae and an increase in coverage of stony corals and crustose coralline algae.
#Text=Similarly, Macia et al (2007) showed a decrease in macroalgae and an increase in the amount of bare space after translocating 508�D. antillarum�with 26% retention after 6 months.
#Text=Unfortunately, not all attempts to restock populations are successful, frequently demonstrating suboptimal retention rates over extended periods.
#Text=This is primarily ascribed to predation (The Nature Conservancy�2004), migration away from the reef (Williams�2018), or a combination of both (Dame�2008; Williams�2022; de Breuyn et al�2023).

#Text=In addition, when a reef ecosystem lacks the requisite shelter space (Macia et al�2007; Burdick�2008; Bodmer et al�2021),�D. antillarum�are more inclined to migrate, which makes them more vulnerable to predation (Carpenter�1984).
#Text=Given that these factors often interact and overlap, distinguishing their individual contributions can prove challenging.

#Text=To determine the main factor that reduces retention, a high frequency of observations during both day and nighttime is needed, which has not been done in previous studies (Burdick�2008; Williams�2022; de Breuyn et al�2023).
#Text=In this study, a restocking experiment was conducted near the island of Saba, Caribbean Netherlands.
#Text=Laboratory_reared�D antillarum�were released onto a patch reef and closely monitored for retention, migration, and predation during a period of 5 weeks.

#Text=In the first week both daytime and nighttime monitoring dives were conducted alongside the deployment of cameras, resulting in 15 hours of diver observations and over 28 hours of time_lapse camera footage.
#Text=Instances of predation, as well as potential predation attempts on the released�D antillarum�were documented and are presented here.
#Text=The findings presented in this study offer valuable insights into the challenges associated with�D antillarum�restocking.
#Text=These insights are instrumental in guiding future proactive interventions aimed at fostering positive effects on reef ecosystems.
#Text=Methods.

#Text=Experimental Setup\rDiadema antillarum�Rearing\rIn total 200 juvenile�Diadema antillarum�sea urchins were reared for the restocking experiment, for 30% originating from larval cultivation and for 70% from settlers collected from the wild.
#Text=In June 2022, larval cultivation took place on Saba, Caribbean Netherlands, following the methods outlined by Wijers et al (2023).
#Text=Concurrently, between April and June 2022, wild settlers were gathered in proximity to the Saban reefs, following Hylkema et al (2022).
#Text=All�D. antillarum�were subsequently reared in 76_L rectangular recirculation tanks for 6_9 months.

#Text=To provide suitable habitat conditions, each tank was equipped with two halves of a 12 cm diameter flower pot and two fist_sized volcanic rocks, offering rugosity and hiding spaces, as these factors could potentially influence shelter behavior (Sharp et al�2018,�2023).
#Text=During the initial 2 months of rearing, a maximum of 50 urchins were maintained in each tank, which was subsequently reduced to a maximum of 20 urchins per tank.
#Text=Within these open polypropylene tanks, filtration, and water circulation was provided by airlift sponge filters.
#Text=Artificial lighting was employed using one Phillips 23w 1,600 lm fluorescent bulb per tank with a 12_hour light and 12_hour dark photoperiod.
#Text=Weekly maintenance included salinity adjustment, the removal of debris from the tank bottoms, followed by a 20% water change.

#Text=As the juveniles were partly reared during the 2022 Caribbean_wide�D. antillarum�die_off (Hylkema et al�2023), tank refreshes were completed using artificial sea water (Tropic Marin salt REEF_MIX) on full strength (35 g/L) during this mortality period and natural sea water was used again from November 2022 onwards, when population recovery was observed on local reefs.
#Text=Juvenile�D. antillarum�were fed thoroughly rinsed macro algae, collected from nearby reefs, and grazer pellets until saturated.
#Text=Nutrients (NO3, NO4, PO4) were tested weekly, and daily temperature fluctuated between 26 and 28 degrees C.

#Text=Two days before release, the mean test size (body without spines) of the reared�D. antillarumwas determined to be 15.8 +/_ 4.0 mm (mean +/_ SD,�n = 200), with the smallest individual measuring 10 mm and the largest reaching 32 mm in size.

#Text=Reef Description\rThe experimental restocking reef was located at Wells Bay at the dive site Torrens Point (17.642637 degrees N, 063.254648 degrees W) and measured approximately 25 m in length and 6 m in width (Fig�1).
#Text=The reef was situated at a depth of 9 m sloping down to a depth of 11 m at the side and featured a nearly 90 degrees  incline leading down to the sand substrate located 1.5_2 m below.

#Text=For the purpose of this study, the reef was subdivided into four quadrants (Fig�1) that were treated as independent replicates, as no movement of urchins between quadrants was observed and to make a clear division for divers/stationary camera observations.
#Text=The size of the four replicate quadrants was defined, taking into account that one team or camera would be able to finalize a full monitoring per time point.
#Text=Ideally, four reefs of similar size and proximity would have been used as replicates, but this was not feasible due to limited resources.
#Text=The border of each quadrant was clearly marked with orange rope, to avoid overlapping observations or counts.
#Text=The reef had substantial structural complexity, providing sufficient crevices as hiding space for the restocked�D. antillarum�(Fig�2).
#Text=Before commencing data collection, the study site was surveyed for the presence of wild�D. antillarum, of which none were found.
#Text=Figure 1\rAn overview and geographical orientation of Saba and the isolated patch reef that was restocked with�Diadema antillarum�at dive location Torrens Point.
#Text=The reef (24.7   6.1 m) was subdivided into four quadrants from top to bottom.
#Text=The middle of the reef was 9.1 m deep, sloping down to a depth of 11.0 m on the sides followed by a steep drop_off to a sandy bottom surrounding the reef 12.6_13.0 m in depth.
#Text=The map of the Caribbean and Saba was created with ArcMap10.8 using data from Esri, HERE, and Garmin.
#Text=Figure 2\rRestocked�Diadema antillarum�are hiding in cervices on the experimental reef on day 1.
#Text=(A_G)�D. antillarumare highlighted with a red arrow and on (H) and (I) the orange line used to mark the division between different quadrants can be seen.
#Text=Restocking\rOn 10 January 2023 (day 0 of the experiment), a total of 180 laboratory_reared�D. antillarumwere used to restock the selected reef.
#Text=On each of the four quadrants, 45 randomly selected urchins were released.
#Text=A team of two divers carefully placed the urchins on the reef, ensuring that they were firmly attached.
#Text=The�D. antillarum�were released in groups in the center of each quadrant, just before sunset (16:30 hours), as this is suggested to improve retention (S.
#Text=Williams 2022, personal communication).
#Text=The center point of release was clearly marked with a reference stick for later use.
#Text=An additional 20�D. antillarum�were kept in two separate cages (1   1   1 m in size) made of rebar and wire mesh of 1 cm gaps adjacent to the reef on the sandy substrate.
#Text=Each cage contained six cinder blocks as habitat and 10�D. antillarum.
#Text=These urchins served as a control group where predation was excluded and they were monitored the first 3 days for health (normal attachment, spine movement, and intact tissue) and survival.

#Text=Following this initial observation period, these control�D. antillarum�were released onto quadrants 2 and 4 at 18:45 hours on day 4 to increase the chance of observing possible predator interactions (see below), totaling 200 released laboratory_reared urchins.
#Text=Monitoring\rD. antillarum�Retention Counts\rRetention counts were conducted on days 1, 3, 4, 9, 14, and finally, 35 around 14:00 hours.
#Text=Divers checked for the total number of�D. antillarum�remaining on the experimental reef.
#Text=In each quadrant, one diver searched for�D. antillarum�for exactly 10 minutes, checking crevices and other potential hiding spots with a torch.
#Text=Roving Diver Survey\rTo assess the presence of potential predators, also on the adjacent reefs, a roving diver visual survey was conducted on day 14 at 9:00 hours.
#Text=This survey was adapted from the fish roving diver technique (Hill & Wilkinson�2004) and involved gathering presence/absence data as well as frequency information.
#Text=In this study, we specifically focused on fishes identified as potential predators.
#Text=In short, two divers systematically inspected the reef areas extending 250 m northward and 250 m eastward from this starting point, dedicating 30 minutes to the survey.
#Text=During this time the presence and sizes were documented of all potential predators of�D. antillarum�in the larger region of interest around and including the test reef area.
#Text=The survey was conducted following a zigzag pattern, with divers scanning an area extending up to 10 m in all directions to ensure the inclusion of more elusive species.

#Text=Divers maintained a slow and consistent pace, trying to traverse hard substrate areas when sand patches were encountered, and actively searched for fish sheltering underneath ledges or within caves, among other potential hiding places.
#Text=Diver Observations\rAfter restocking, day (09:00_13:45 hours) and nighttime (18:45_20:00 hours) observations were conducted by teams of 2   2 divers.

#Text=On days 1, 3, and 4 (no monitoring on day 2 due to bad weather), four divers completed a 40_minute stationary point count, followed by a 20_minute stationary point count in a second dive, each diver monitoring on of the four quadrants.

#Text=Similar night monitoring dives of 30 minutes were conducted by two teams of divers, each with a dive torch (BigBlue AL1300XWP) with a red filter as red light is less visible for most fish and sea urchins (Fitzpatrick et al�2013; Yang et al�2020).

#Text=This was done on night 0 (directly after release), night 1 and night 3 and resulted in 240 minutes of daytime observations and 60 minutes of nighttime observations on each of these days (Table�1).
#Text=Table 1.
#Text=�Total minutes of camera recording (including total number of photos), during day_ (11:00 hours) and nighttime (18:00 hours) and total dive time predator observations in minutes.
#Text=*On day 1, only one of the four cameras worked and on day 2, one camera malfunctioned both day and night.
#Text=�#The weather conditions on day 2 were too rough, therefore no data were collected.

#Text=Day\rTime\rCameras (minutes) (# of photos)\rDivers (minutes)\r0\rNight\r17 (201)*\r60\r1\rDay\r445 (5330)*\r240\r\rNight\r292 (3,509)\r60\r2#\rDay\r_\r_\r\rNight\r_\r_\r3\rDay\r569 (6826)\r240\r\rNight\r371 (4447)\r60\r4\rDay\r_\r240\r\rTotal\r1,693 (20313)\r900\rDivers observed the presence of potential�D. antillarum�predators and damselfish.

#Text=Even though damselfish do not predate on�D. antillarum, they were included as they are known to move�D. antillarum�from their territory (Behrents et al�1984), pecking and even chasing introduced�D. antillarum�(Williams�2022).

#Text=The list of potential predators included black margate�Anisotremus surinamensis, Spanish grunt�Haemulon macrostomum, Caesar grunt�Haemulon carbonarium, white grunt�Haemulon plumierii, bluestriped grunt�Haemulon sciurus, jolthead porgy�Calamus bajonado, saucereye porgy�Calamus calamus, Spanish hogfish�Bodianus rufus, Caribbean spiny lobster�Panulirus argus, queen triggerfish�Balistes vetula, bandtail puffer�Sphoeroides spengleri, spotted porcupine fish�Diodon hysterix, puddingwife�Halichoeres radiatus, King helmet�Cassis tuberosa, and queen helmet�Cassis madagascariensis, based on Randall et al (1964).

#Text=We also included the Caribbean spiny lobster�P. argus�based on Randall et al (1964), the spotted spiny lobster�Panulirus guttatus�based on Kintzing and Butler (2014), and the batwing coral crab�Carpilius corallinus�based on Sharp and Reckenbeil (2022).
#Text=Observations included identifying predatory species that were present on the reef and the estimation of their size and behavior.
#Text=Behavior was classified as possibly interacting with_, attacking_, or eating�D. antillarum�(Fig�3).
#Text=This resulted in the following three possible scores:\r1.
#Text=Possible interaction = Predator is possibly interacting with�D. antillarum.
#Text=View of�D. antillarum�and/or predator is partly obsucred by the reef, but predator could be attacking�D. antillarum.\r2.
#Text=Interaction = Predator is seen actively attacking a�D. antillarum.\r3.
#Text=Successful attack = Predator is seen with a�D. antillarum�in the mouth, eating/chewing on a�D. antillarum.

#Text=Figure 3\rScored behavior showing the reef with the zoomed in interaction of (A) a possible interaction, score 1, where the view is hindered, (B) a Spanish hogfish interacting with a�Diadema antillarum, score 2, during daytime, (C) an interacting batwing coral crab, score 2, during night and (D) a successful attack, score 3, during daytime with the�D. antillarum�clearly in the mouth of a Spanish hogfish.
#Text=Once an interaction was observed, the diver would observe the animal interacting for a total of 3 minutes and attribute the highest interaction score to the interaction.

#Text=At the end of each night dive, two teams of divers would systematically check the sand surrounding the experimental reef for potentially migrating urchins for a total time of 10 minutes and score the number of�D. antillarum�seen.

#Text=Stationary Camera Observations\rTo assess predation and predator presence on the reef, especially when divers are not present, stationary cameras (GoPro Hero 8 Black) were deployed on days 0, 1, and 3 of the experiment.
#Text=Four cameras were installed on temporary frames, with one camera for each quadrant of the experimental reef.
#Text=Cameras were pointed on the part of the reef with the highest density of�D. antillarum�present to increase the sighting of predator interactions.
#Text=The stationary cameras took photos every 5 seconds, day (starting at 11:00 hours) and night (starting at 18:00 hours).
#Text=For camera vision at night, red lights (BigBlue AL1300XWP with red filter dive torch) were installed to minimize the effect of lighting on reef inhabitant behavior.
#Text=A total of 12,156 usable daytime photos and 8,157 nighttime photos were taken, resulting in 1013 and 680 minutes of footage, respectively (Table�1).
#Text=During the first night, only 17 minutes of footage were recorded due to camera malfunction.
#Text=On day 1, the camera for quadrant 4 failed, and a loose camera_strap and high densities of zooplankton rendered about half of the photos of quadrants 1 and 3 unusable.

#Text=Photo Analyses\rEach usable photo was carefully searched for the presence of known predators and interactions with�D. antillarum, scored similar to the three interactions described above in the�Diver observations.
#Text=Because photos were taken only 5 seconds apart, a predator usually appeared in a sequence of multiple photos.

#Text=We considered visits as independent only if they were separated from other photos of a conspecific predator by at least 10 minutes (600 photos), or if multiple successful attacks at different locations were observed within the 10_minute timeframe.
#Text=Possible interactions were checked for possible overlapping, due to the use of multiple cameras, and only scored once.
#Text=Photos were only attributed to the highest level code describing the action of the observed predator.
#Text=Results.
#Text=Diadema antillarum�Retention\rAfter the first night, on day 1, retention on the restocked reef was 41.7 +/_ 25.7% (average +/_ SD; Fig�4).
#Text=On day 35, two quadrants had zero�Diadema antillarum�and two quadrants had one�D. antillarum�out of the total 200 restocked urchins.
#Text=No mortality or abnormal health issues were recorded among the 20�D. antillarum�housed in the two control cages during the monitoring period of 3 days.
#Text=Also, no�D. antillarum�were observed migrating away from the reef during day and nighttime observations.
#Text=Figure 4\rRecovered�Diadema antillarum�as percentage of total number of restocked�D. antillarum; mean +/_ SD of the four quadrants, over a total period of 35 days.

#Text=*At the end of day 3, quadrants 2 and 4, received 10 additional�D. antillarum�each from the control cages, increasing the number of released urchins in these quadrants only and thus increasing the standard deviation for day 4.
#Text=Predator Presence\rRoving Diver Survey\rFrom the list of potential predators, four different species were observed during the roving diver survey (Table�2).
#Text=Spanish hogfish were most frequently observed, followed by black margate.
#Text=Table 2.

#Text=�Daytime roving diver survey results, showing the total number of observations of each of the observed potential predator, the total number of individual fish, and the average estimated size +/_ SD.

#Text=Species\rObservations\rTotal count\rSize (cm)\rSpanish hogfish\r7\r8\r15.3 +/_ 8.7\rBlack margate\r3\r4\r13.7 +/_ 2.5\rJolthead porgy\r1\r1\r35 +/_ 0\rPorcupine fish\r1\r1\r35 +/_ 0\rDiver Observations\rDuring daytime diver predator observations, Spanish hogfish, bluestriped grunt, puddingwife, smooth trunkfish, sharpnose puffer, spotted trunkfish, spiny lobster, and spotted lobster were observed on the reef.
#Text=The Spanish hogfish was the most observed potential predator, with 27 individuals with an estimated average size of 18.7 +/_ 5.5 cm (mean +/_ SD).
#Text=Divers also identified bicolor damselfish�Stegastes partitus, longfin damselfish�Stegastes diencaeus, sergeant major�Abudefduf saxatilis, and yellowtail damselfish�Microspathodon chrysurus.
#Text=At night, divers observed the potential predator species batwing coral crab, king helmet, queen helmet, and spotted spiny�lobster.
#Text=The batwing coral crab was the most frequently observed predator during nighttime, with a total of 14 observations and an estimated average carapace width of 6.8 +/_ 2.0 cm.
#Text=Camera Observations\rStationary camera photo analyses yielded no additional species for daytime observations.
#Text=At night, active black margate and smooth trunkfish were also seen on camera footages which were not identified during diver observations.

#Text=Observed Interactions\rDiver Observations\rOut of the possible nine predator species seen on the reef, Spanish hogfish was the only species that was seen to interact with the released�D. antillarum�during diver observations (Table�3).
#Text=In total, five successful attacks by Spanish hogfish were observed, all on day 1.
#Text=The estimated size of the Spanish hogfish with a successful attack was between 20 and 25 cm.
#Text=Also, none of the four observed damselfish species interacted with the�D. antillarum.
#Text=In addition to the observed interactions, the day after restocking, numerous spine fragments and one spineless test from�D. antillarum�were discovered on the reef.
#Text=Table 3.
#Text=�Diadema antillarum�predator interactions scored by divers during the day and night, total number of interactions, and number of interactions per hours of observation.

#Text=Predator interactions are scored as: 1 Species is possibly interacting with�D. antillarum, Predator could be hidden in crevice or view can be partly obscured by parts of the reef or other structures; 2 Species observed actively attacking a�D. antillarum; 3 Species observed eating/chewing a�D. antillarum.

#Text=Species\r\rSpanish hogfish\rDay\rTime\rInteractions (#/hour)\r\r\r1\r2\r3\r0\rNight\r_\r_\r_\r1\rDay\r5 (1.25)\r1 (0.25)\r5 (1.25)\r\rNight\r_\r_\r_\r3\rDay\r_\r2 (0.5)\r_\r\rNight\r_\r_\r_\r4\rDay\r2 (0.25)\r_\r_\rNotably, during diver observations, Spanish hogfish frequently exhibited hunting behavior in pairs, with a larger individual measuring approximately 25 cm followed by a smaller one measuring approximately 15 cm.
#Text=These pairs traversed the reefs in a zigzag motion, twisting their bodies (due to their side_facing eyes) and inspecting crevices.
#Text=Upon identifying prey, the larger individual would initiate the attack by first attempt to dislodge the urchin from the side and, if successful, seizing it with their mouth (Video�S1).
#Text=In a successful attack, the smaller Spanish hogfish, as well as other fish present, would then opportunistically feed on parts of�D. antillarum�broken off by the larger Spanish hogfish.
#Text=Camera Observations\rFour successful attacks were captured by the stationary cameras (Table�4).
#Text=�On each of these photos, a Spanish hogfish was clearly seen with a�D. antillarum�in its mouth.
#Text=Table 4.
#Text=�Diadema antillarum�predator interactions scored by photographic analyses, both day and night, total number of interactions, and number of interactions per hours of observation.

#Text=Predator interactions are scored as: 1 Species is possibly interacting with�D. antillarum, Predator could be hidden in crevice or view can be partly obscured by parts of the reef or other structures; 2 Species observed actively attacking a�D. antillarum; 3 Species observed eating/chewing a�D. antillarum.

#Text=Species\r\rSpanish hogfish\rBatwing coral crab\rDay\rTime\rInteractions (#/hour)\r\r\r1\r2\r3\r1\r2\r3\r0\rNight\r_\r_\r_\r_\r_\r_\r1\rDay\r_\r2 (0.27)\r4 (0.54)\r_\r_\r_\r\rNight\r_\r_\r_\r_\r_\r_\r3\rDay\r_\r2 (0.21)\r_\r_\r_\r_\r\rNight\r_\r_\r_\r_\r1 (0.16)\r_\rThe only recorded interaction during nighttime occurred on day 4.
#Text=A batwing coral crab attacked a�D. antillarum, seemingly removed some spines, after which the�D. antillarummoved away.
#Text=Discussion.
#Text=Overall retention of restocked�Diadema antillarum�in this research was low, with less than 5% of the urchins recovered after 9 days and only two of a total of 200 after 35 days.
#Text=Spanish hogfish were identified as the main diurnal predator, with nine successful attacks recorded through a combination of stationary cameras and diver observations.
#Text=One interaction with a batwing coral crab was observed during the night, though no successful attack were recorded.
#Text=This strongly suggests daytime predation as the primary factor contributing to the low retention rate and is strengthened by the fact that no migration off the experimental reef was observed.

#Text=The decline in retention found in this research was steeper compared to de Breuyn et al (2023), who still had over 25% retention, with both wild and laboratory_reared�D. antillarum, 10 days after restocking.
#Text=They released�D. antillarum�on small artificial reefs, providing shelter, which might explain the higher retention compared to our findings.
#Text=�D. antillarumshelter during daylight hours, emerging from their hiding spots during the night (Randall et al�1964; Behrents et al�1984).

#Text=Even though the reef seemed to have sufficient hiding space for the�D. antillarum, perhaps the size of the crevices was not right (Bodmer et al�2021), or the reef lacked sufficient rugosity in general (Tuohy et al�2020).

#Text=The observed instances of predation during the daytime indicate that the hiding spaces available may not have been sufficiently effective, or released lab_cultured individuals did not have sufficient awareness or time to establish where adequate shelter may be found.
#Text=Adding extra hiding spaces (Dame�2008), structures (de Breuyn et al�2023), or corrals (Williams�2022) could increase retention and could be considered in future restocking attempts.

#Text=Spanish hogfish is a large wrasse species that inhabits depths ranging from 3 to 33 m and predominantly prey on invertebrates such as crabs, brittle stars (Randall�1967), and also on�D. antillarum�(Randall et al�1964).
#Text=While in our study, the Spanish hogfish was the main diurnal predator, de Breuyn et al (2023) identified the queen triggerfish�Balistes vetula�as the main predator.

#Text=Interestingly, we observed no queen triggerfish around our experiment reef during any of our observations, even though it was only a few kilometers away from the experimental site of de Breuyn et al (2023).

#Text=Although potential predators were observed on and around the reef during both daytime and nighttime observations, no species was seen interacting with�D. antillarum�other than the batwing coral crab during the nighttime observation.
#Text=It is clear that sea urchin densities are linked to predator abundance (Brown_Saracino et al�2007; Hernandez et al�2008; Harborne et al�2009).
#Text=The reefs surrounding Saba are a National Marine Park where commercial fishing is prohibited, which paradoxically poses challenges for the restoration of�D. antillarum.
#Text=Harborne et al (2009) concluded that the likelihood of�D. antillarum�populations recovering in marine reserves is low due to the elevated abundance of meso_predatory fish.

#Text=This has been observed in the Canary Islands as well, where densities of�D. antillarum africanum�are lower inside marine protected areas (MPAs) compared to highly fished areas nearby (Hernandez et al�2008).
#Text=In addition, it was observed that more urchins fall prey within these MPAs compared to areas outside (Clemente et al�2011).
#Text=Selecting reefs with low predator densities, especially of Spanish hogfish and queen triggerfish, is likely to increase the retention of restocked�D. antillarum.
#Text=We observed four species of damselfish, but none of them interacted with the released�D. antillarum.
#Text=Bicolor damselfish are territorial throughout the year but mainly when nesting (Myrberg�1972), similar to sergeant major (Albrecht�1969) and longfin damselfish (Cheney & C�t��2003).
#Text=Also, yellowtail damselfish are known to share their territory with other species (Di Santo et al�2020) and are not particularly known to be aggressive toward urchins.
#Text=The three_spot damselfish�Stegastes planifrons�seems to be most aggressive toward�D. antillarum(Williams�1981; Behrents et al�1984), including released�D. antillarum�(Williams�2022).
#Text=However, three spot damselfish were not seen on our experimental reef, explaining why no interaction with damselfish were observed.
#Text=In future experiments, it is advised to limit monitoring efforts to the three_spot damselfish.
#Text=The source of the restocked urchins could also contribute to the low retention rate of our research.
#Text=There are indications that laboratory_reared�D. antillarum�exhibit lower fitness levels compared to their wild counterparts (The Nature Conservancy�2004; Sharp et al�2018).

#Text=Reared�D. antillarum�tend to have more brittle spines and may therefore be more susceptible to predation (The Nature Conservancy�2004), in addition to displaying possibly less effective shelter behavior compared to wild�D. antillarum�(Sharp et al�2018).
#Text=The shelter behavior of the urchins released in this study appeared normal; however, they were picked off the reef by predators quite easily, even when hiding in a crevice.
#Text=There are indications that sea urchins have different tube feet strength in laboratory conditions compared to wild urchins (Narvaez et al�2020), explaining these observations.
#Text=With an average size of 15.8 mm, the�D. antillarum�used in this study were relatively small, which may have contributed to the high predation rates by the Spanish hogfish.
#Text=�D. antillarumlarger than 15 mm seem safe from predation from the spiny spotted lobster (Kintzing & Butler�2014).
#Text=On the other hand, Clemente et al (2011) observed that�D. africanum�with a test size of 20_30 mm were more frequently preyed upon compared to urchins over 40 mm in size.
#Text=As the survival of prey often depends on the size of the predator's mouth (Wainwright�1988,�1991), larger urchins are more likely to survive predation events.
#Text=It was also the larger Spanish hogfish observed here that conducted the successful attacks.
#Text=It is likely that had we used larger�D. antillarum, the survival rate would be higher.
#Text=However, rearing urchins to a larger size requires substantial resources, which are often limited.
#Text=For the restocking of herbivorous Caribbean king crabs�Maguimithrax spinosissimus, a minimum size of 30 mm was determined to be sufficient to deter most predators (Spadaro & Butler�2021).

#Text=A similar size threshold could potentially be identified for�D. antillarum, with indications that a size above 26_40 mm could be sufficient (Clemente et al�2011; Kintzing & Butler�2014), where increased survival could warrant the extra effort of rearing for a longer time.
#Text=Besides urchin size, the total number of�D. antillarum�released can also affect restocking success.
#Text=Swamping predators with a large number of offspring is a known strategy in nature, eg in seabirds (Descamps�2019), salmon, and also sea urchins (Hagen & Mann�1992).
#Text=However, in this research, over 100 urchins were gone within 1 day.
#Text=To swamp predators, this would translate to thousands of urchins, which is not realistic with current culture techniques and rearing facilities (Pilnick et al�2022; Wijers et al�2023).

#Text=Rearing effort and costs could potentially be reduced by utilizing in situ grow_out systems such as artificial structures (James et al�2007), sea cages, already used for sea cucumbers (Purcell et al�2012) and�D. antillarum�(Brittsan et al�2023), or other (semi) natural sheltered habitats.
#Text=This could also be useful to protect sea urchins while they grow bigger and acclimate better to living on a natural reef.

#Text=Also, if the number of available urchins is no longer constraining experimental setup, true reef replicates, instead of quadrants, could be used and tested at different locations, ultimately increasing the chance of high retentions and successful restocking practices.
#Text=Prior studies were also constrained by the absence of nighttime observations (de Breuyn et al�2023), thus limiting the ability to directly observe predation events.
#Text=Given that infrared/thermal cameras are mostly ineffective underwater, the utilization of red light was considered a viable alternative.

#Text=Although observations of predation were observed, there were indications (personal observations) that both potential predators and�D. antillarumactively avoided the red light, potentially leading to a reduction in observed interactions.

#Text=The sea urchin�Strongylocentrotus intermedius�exhibits a significantly lower foraging activity in white and blue light compared to red light (Yang et al�2020), supporting the use of red light for observations.
#Text=Nevertheless, the use of red light may still influence the behavior of some predators on a natural reef, potentially limiting the number of interactions observed.
#Text=Still, our results suggest that nighttime predation was not the main cause for the decline in�D. antillarum�in this study.
#Text=Besides the single interaction observed by the cameras, divers did not observe any interaction during night dives, even though predators were observed to be present on the experimental reef.
#Text=The released urchins may have already been too large to have been preyed upon by spotted spiny lobster as they are known to prefer�D. antillarumsmaller than 10 mm (Kintzing & Butler�2014).
#Text=Despite some of the constraints, the findings presented in this study enhance our comprehension of the mechanisms influencing the success of�D. antillarum�restocking efforts.

#Text=In addition to the observations noted by Sharp and Reckenbeil (2022), this study represents one of the few investigations to document direct predation on restocked�D. antillarum, utilizing both diver observations and photographic evidence, and the first to observe active interaction during nocturnal hours.

#Text=Based on our findings, the selection of location, including the presence of high densities of known predators, especially Spanish hogfish, seems an important consideration in the planning of�D. antillarum�restocking initiatives.
#Text=Preferably, sites with significant numbers of known predators should be avoided.
#Text=An alternative strategy could involve predator removal before restocking.
#Text=However, the effects are often short_term and challenging to predict beforehand (Lennox et al�2018).
#Text=Habituating reared urchins to the natural environment in a closed_off, or semi_natural environment, while giving them time to grow into a less vulnerable size could also aid survival.
#Text=Moreover, future research should prioritize elucidating the optimal size for restocking�D. antillarum.

#Text=If larger�D. antillarum�exhibit significantly reduced predation rates, investing additional resources in rearing them for an extended duration may be warranted and is something that should be studied further.

#Text=Acknowledgments\rThe experiments were conducted within the scope of the RAAK PRO Diadema project (project# RAAK.PRO03.005), partially funded by SIA, part of the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research (NWO).

#Text=The authors want to thank Puck Heerink and Rick Verkooijen for data collection assistance, Alex van der Last for helping with the underwater camera setup and Arend Melchior Kroos for helping with the editing of the maps and photo figures.
#Text=Finally, we want to thank the Saba Conservation Foundation staff, especially Marijn van der Laan, for providing logistical support.
